Key Messages
Persisting insurgent activities in the northeast of Nigeria, coupled with trade restrictions, population displacements, restricted road access during the rainy season, and arrivals of refugees from Niger and Cameroon have continued to drive severe acute food insecurity and limit the efforts of humanitarian partners in providing assistance to displaced persons in the region. A substantial proportion of the population in the northeast continues to face Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or Emergency (IPC Phase 4) acute food insecurity, with an increased risk of high levels of acute malnutrition and excess mortality. Less accessible areas remain at risk of Famine (IPC Phase 5).
As of September 27th, 4,114 cases of cholera have been reported in Borno State, with 56 deaths and a Case Fatality Rate of 1.4 percent. High concentrations of the outbreak have been reported in the Muna corridor of Jere LGA (1,991 cases), Dikwa LGA (687 cases), and Monguno LGA (1,396 cases), while cases in Maiduguri metropolitan area and Mafa stand at 34 and 6, respectively. Suspected cases have been identified as being at ‘high risk’ in Bama, Biu, Kala Balge, Kukawa, Mobbar, Ngala, Hawul, Damboa, and Gwoza local government areas.
Households outside of the northeast of Nigeria are engaged in early harvests of millet, maize, cowpea, groundnut, and cassava, and are consuming own-produced foods. Similarly, the favorable main season harvest which is underway in localized areas has led to increased availability and a decline in staple food prices, improving food access for poor households. Most poor households in these areas are engaged in normal income earning opportunities and are facing Minimal (IPC Phase 1) acute food insecurity.
Heavy rainfall events and above-average cumulative precipitation in much of Nigeria and the neighboring countries of Niger and Cameroon led to flooding in at least 22 states in Nigeria, including significant impacts in Benue, Kogi, Niger, Ebonyi, and Delta States. In Benue and Kogi States, flooding led to the displacement of over 250,000 people who are currently living in camps. Similarly, some houses have been destroyed and cropped fields damaged. The government and humanitarian partners are currently providing food and non-food support, including access to water for the displaced persons.
The preliminary results of a joint WFP/FEWS NET market survey showed that market functioning in conflict-affected areas of Borno, Yobe, and Adamawa States are gradually improving. However, staple food prices remain higher relative to the same time last year and well-above average price levels. Household demand remains elevated by 70, 63 and 64 percent, across Borno, Yobe and Adamawa States, respectively, relative to the same period of last year.

I rate this one higher than the Yemen question, but "Famine" headlines for FEWS Alerts are rare.
Dec - Feb headlines used "famine" but they have not been used since. Historically, famine rarely occurs in headlines.

South Sudan is fighting social unrest and rebel fighters are causing farmers to flee for survival causing economic instability in the region for food stuffs. The UN has set sanctions and the US is already providing aide to fight famine.

The harvest period in both countries has begun. FEWS currently projects continued food emergencies (IPC Phase 4) in parts of these countries but does not project a famine (IPC Phase 5) in the near term. That said, FEWS sometimes issues food security alerts containing the word "famine" when it is reporting the potential for famine, not the presence of famine.

1. South Sudan has received FEWS famine status alert in past year and they are still in crisis with acute malnutrition for >15% of population.  Harvest season has started which will help but crop production is below average levels.  I see South Sudan as the higher probability for a famine warning.
2. An August report from FEWS notes Nigeria's northeast in elevated risk of famine due to ongoing Boko Haram conflict - limiting access to food and livilehood.  This area will continue to rely heavily on aid,  For the rest of the country, the situation is less dire and crop production is expected to be above average.
3. As noted by another responder; FEWS NET could use the word famine in an alert to indicate no famine.  I'm not sure if or how often this has been done previously but it does slightly increase the probability of a "yes" response to this question.

Only 3% of all alerts each month contain the word famine. Famine related headlines peak in June - August and taper off after that. The affected regions seem to be stabilizing and in some cases improving.
South Sudan doesn't seem to be in imminent danger of a famine and if there is a famine in Nigeria it would be in Boko Haram areas that can't get word out to the wider world.

In January 2017, FEWS NET warned that four countries (Nigeria, Somalia, South Sudan, and Yemen) would face face a credible risk of Famine (IPC Phase 5) in 2017, but issued no famine alerts regarding either Nigeria or South Sudan since then.   In South Sudan, the lean summer season is over and weather patterns in the autumn tend to be more conducive to food crop cultivation and harvest. On the negative side, USAID is undertaking a review of its food assistance program to South Sudan but I doubt that will lead to a rapid drawdown in food distribution. In Nigeria armed conflict continues to drive the good insecurity crisis, especially in inaccessible areas in the northeast. "Famine-like" condition are reported, but the UN World Food Program (WFP) is now rushing thousands of tons of rice and other foodstuffs to the area, hopefully alleviating some of the famine.
I think this is possible but uncertain as to timing.

Updating - the criteria for an official famine are pretty stringent. FEWS NET's own projections show most areas in both Nigeria and South Sudan having decreased risk of famine in the upcoming month. The FEWS NET alerts have not used Famine and South Sudan OR Nigeria in a headline in 8 months.

While it appears that South Sudan is out of the woods; Nigeria, particularly Northeast Nigeria is experiencing a lean season due to flooding in the region. Food insecurity levels has risen. Boko Haram also appears to be a contributing factor relating to food insecurity. I'll have to do more research though.
